Background. Today's environmentof heightened confrontationand risk in West Bank and Gaza (WBG), including the tightening of movement and access restrictions, has led to a severe contraction in Palestinian economic activity, particularly over the past 10 months. This, coupled with fiscal distress, has contributedto the hardshipand difficulties faced by all Palestinians on a daily basis. Damaged infrastructure due to the conflict and, in many cases, the inability to maintain, repair and rehabilitate such service infrastructuredue to lack of financing or access to it, has severely compromised the ability of central and local agencies to continue rendering services to their communities. These circumstances place the average Palestinianin situationsof increased exposure to health and sanitation risks (mounting and decomposing solid waste throughout heavily populated urban areas), irregular supply of potable water and electricity, public safety risks due to unlit and damaged streets, and ongoingdegradation of the environment that will affect future generations of Palestinians, in addition to the well-documented psychological trauma and post traumatic distress syndrome that is increasingly witnessed in the behaviorof children andyouth as a direct consequenceof the ongoingcrisis'.
Sharp Declines in Economic Activity. Border closures have been increasingly tightened as an Israeli security measure over recent months and for prolonged periods with uncertainty about when they will be lifted or re-imposedthereafter. This has had a dramatic effect on the normal conduct of commercial activities. Movement restrictions on goods and people (not only to external markets but also to local markets) remainthe foremost binding constraintson economic activity, significantly raising uncertainty and the cost of doing business. Palestinian access to jobs in Israel, which is a vital component of the Gazan economy has dwindled to negligible levels. Over the past few months, trucks carrying goods for export from Gaza have dropped by 40 percent over the already low level of exports transiting out of Gaza at the beginningof 2005. Food supplies and other household commodities have also been held up at border crossingpoints resultingin sharp increases inthe pricesof domestic consumables.
Unemployment Remains High. Continued restrictions on the passage of goods and people and further extensions of the separation wall have severely affected the growth capacity of the Palestinianeconomy. Despitesome initial steps toward recovery in 2005, GDP per capita(in real terms) remains well its 1999 (pre-Intifada) level. Unemploymentremains severe, at around 25 percent, compared with 11.9 percent in 1999, pointing to the continued and acute inability of the Palestinian economy to fully utilize its productive assets. Gaza has been especially hard hit. Almost 19,000 full timejobs were lost in Gaza due to border closures over the past six monthsor more than 10 percent of all full timejobs. As jobs in Gaza have disappeared, more of the labor force has entered into part-timeemployment, and the number of underemployedin Gazahas risen by some 60% over the last six months (and by morethan 80% relativeto Q2 2005).
Poverty Incidence Continues its Upward Trend. With a high population growth rate in WBG and declining real per capita incomes, poverty has been on the increase, with the poverty rate almost doubling following the outbreak of the Intifada, to an estimated 41 percent by the end of 2006. Most Palestinians report that they have exhausted prior coping strategies of borrowing from families, relatives and friends, purchasing essential household commodities on credit, and sellingfamily gold andjewelry to cover the needs.
IA recent survey by Neareast Consulting (September 2006) found that more than 75 percent ofthe Palestinianpopulation in WBG is clinically depressed, noting an increase of 21 percent injust one year, with particularly highrates amongrefugeecamp and urban dwellers.

Distressed Municipalities and Mounting Financial Arrears. Mounting municipal arrears represent a key challenge in the sector and point to the high risk exposure of LGs in times of financial crisis when citizens are unable to pay for electricity, water and other services delivered by LGs. Municipal financial arrears alone are estimated to have reached approximatelyNIS450 million at the close of 2004 and continueto expand each month, as many households simply lack the ability to pay. One important caveat is that more than 70 percent of these arrears are concentrated at the ten largest municipalities, suggesting that a well-targeted strategy, including work out plans for each of the distressed municipalities, could be achievable in the short- to medium-term, if coupled with a longer-termstrategy of establishinga hard budget constraintthat is enforced at the central level, while considering reassignment of some revenue collection responsibilitiesto the local level.
Emergency Assessments. As noted in the forgoing, the nature of the emergency situation that prevails in WBG today is complex in that it is the result of a range of different factors, including the impact of direct conflict in damaging human and physicalassets, facilities and infrastructure; a severe and prolonged economic downturn (accompanied by high rates of unemployment and very limited levels of new private investment) with few immediate prospects for recovery; political stalemate in putting the peace process back on track; and an unravelingof some of the critical donor assistanceand support structures, and, consequently, aid flows. Such circumstances might best be characterized as a "slow onset disaster." A number of different assessments have been carried out which attempt to quantify and in other ways characterize the nature of the emergency. Most recently (September 2006), the Municipal Development and Lending Fund (MDLF) carried out a survey of over 100 municipalities. The survey revealed that, on balance, municipal revenues were approximately36 percent below their already contracted level from the previous year, thus highlightingthe fiscal dimensionof the emergency at the local level. Nablus Municipality, for example, reports that it is only able to collect 18 percent of the electricity service fees it charges to its customers. This is generally attributable to the high and prolonged level of unemployment that has prevailedover the past year where in most cases citizens do not have the ability to meet their service cost obligations. This has resulted in the contraction of many essential municipalservicesthat will requirebudgetary support to be sustained.
Municipality Identiped Assistance Needs. The MDLF survey highlights a number of essential municipal services for which support is being requested, namely rehabilitation of internal municipalroads damaged due to conflict or worn due to deferred maintenance; private contractor expenses for removingdebris from damaged buildings, for solid waste collection and for landfill tipping fees; fuel to operate water pumps, electrical generators, and for service vehicles, particularly for solid waste collection, to increase collection visits; electricity for street lighting and bulbs, poles and lamps to repair existing lights. Many water wells and wastewater pumping stations are reported to be operating at sub-optimal levels because of a lack of spare parts. Electricity shortages have ledto an overuse of standby diesel generators at water and wastewater stations, increasing the operating costs to municipalitiesand often causing damage to sensitive equipment due to frequent power surges and cuts. Moreover, the depreciation of roads throughout WBG is accelerating, as they are no longer being properly cleaned and maintained because of municipal revenue shortfalls and the need to focus expenditures on only the most essential services.
4  Municipality Coping Strategies. Municipalities, many of which actually pre-date the Palestinian Authority, have endured and provento be quite resilient during prolongedperiods of conflict and economic depression, while trying to address essential municipal service needs. Particularly over the past several years where their revenues have generally been declining, they have had to resort to a range of different coping strategies. These have included efforts to enhance local revenue collection for services by including solid waste removal fees on electricity and water bills; offering discounts and other incentive schemes to promote cost recovery, including graduated payments; conductingpublic awareness campaigns and addressing their constituents in mosques and other public venues to stress the need for payment for services; expanding operatinghours to make access to the municipality easier for payingcustomers; suspending plannedrecruitmentand removingovertime incentivesor eliminatingannual salary increases; and payingcommissions to debt collectors. Other harsher means have also been taken, including denial of service to some households and off-setting PA salaries to settle overdue accounts. Some improvements in local revenue collection have been noted in 2006 following local government elections and based on the increased legitimacy of local councils following a hiatus of 30 years in which local elections had been suspended.

SECTION B. BANK RESPONSE & STRATEGY
In the absence of a conventional Country Assistance Strategy (CAS), the Executive Directors approved on December 2, 2003 a document that outlines the Status of the Bank's Program in WBG & Strategy GoingForward. This document outlinesthe Bank's proposed strategy in WBG for 2004 and beyond (until such time as a new strategy is adopted) and, in particularemphasizes the Bank's focus on "maintaining medium-term development activity where feasible and providingemergency assistancedesigned to sustain Palestinianinstitutionsand mitigatepoverty". EMSRP Iwas one component of that strategy and was acknowledged to be an important instrument, not only in addressing local-level emergency needs, but also in helping the PA to establish a rational, transparent and predictable intergovernmentaltransfer system.
Rationale for the Bank's Involvement. The Bank has considerable global and WBG-specific experience in designing and implementing emergency operations in response to emergencies arisingdue to conflict or naturaldisasters. InWBG in particular, the Bank is often relied uponto lead such efforts. The first three operations implemented by the Bank in WBG4were all emergency in nature and benefited from simplicity in design, while contributing toward the establishment of Palestinian implementation capacity in the absence of such capacity at the outset. Moreover, the Bank has demonstrated an ability to respond rapidly to emergency needs through its US$12 million contribution to the Emergency Response Program', launched in December 2000 - only two months after the start of the Intifada -- in which the Bank and five other donors providedover US$37 million to create temporary employment opportunitiesthrough small-scale infrastructure microprojects. Furthermore, the Bank's ability to mobilize resources and to contribute by providing a framework for other donor assistance is illustrated by the Emergency Services Support Project, which has mobilizedsubstantial donor cofinancingover the years. Similarly, EMSRP I was able to mobilize cofinancing from the European Union (30 million Euro), the Italian Government (25 million Euro) and the Government of Denmark (56.5 millionDanishKroner).

Lessons Learned from Previous Similar Operations. A major lesson learned from recent emergency operations supported by the Bank is that developing countries are becoming increasingly aware of the need to put in place measuresto prevent or reduce risks arising due to crises. The past ten years have seen an increase in the number of Bank-supportedemergency recovery projects, and also a steep learning curve in the Bank's own understanding of how to operationalizesustainable interventions.
With respect to Bank experience in WBG, complementary approaches adopted by ESSP (in providing support to sustain centrally-providededucation, health and social services) andEMSRP (supporting localities in providingmunicipalservices) have demonstrated that the Bank and other donors need to focus on both central and local levels. Over centralization of service administration and delivery can result in implementation delays, and mobility restrictions in WBG in particular have shown that greater decentralizationin the assignment of responsibilities i s essential for effectiveness and to achieve impact. Based on the findings of a recent review of EMSRP I,it was further noted that the project scope was too broad, aiming to address over 400 localities,thus spreading too thinly limited resources while limiting the Project's impact. These lessons learnedhave been incorporatedinto the proposedproject's design, as EMSRP I1would be targetingonly the 131 municipal areas, while other Bank interventions(particularlythe Integrated Community Development Project) would aim to target refugee camps and smaller village councils and communities.
Building further on learning gained from EMSRP I,implementation of the proposed project would be managed on a day-to-daybasisby afully staffed entity inthe newly-establishedMDLF, which attributes its establishment to the support, provided under EMSRP I.To ensure project flexibility and responsiveness to different community needs and to circumvent prevailing mobility restrictions, the design of EMSRP I1 retains the demand-driven arrangement and decentralized implementation approach of its predecessor, whereby local governments, in consultation with their communities (to the extent possible), would determine their own emergency assistance priorities and would implement projects at the local level, including preparation of emergency programs, tendering, contracting and supervising implementation, under the guidance of the MDLF. This approach would be reinforcedby the engagement of four regionally-basedteams of technical consultants who would provide monitoring, implementation support and training to participating municipalities. Streamlined Bank procurement procedures would be used to facilitate implementationand experience and capacity gained by MDLF from implementingEMSRP Iand other donor funds would facilitate implementation and the flow of funds.
Another key lesson learned from past experience is the need for effective donor coordination, both before and during project implementation. In the preparationof EMSRP 11,every donor providing assistance to the local government sector was consulted to inform the Project's design. Agreement was reached to design the approach and allocation mechanism with maximum flexibility to take into account other donors' financing requirements as well their respective comparative advantages. Coordinationwith GTZ in designinga broad-basedtechnical assistance strategy for WBG local governments is under preparationwith the aim of rationalizing donor interventions in the sector. It was further agreed with the PA, MDLF and donor partners that a Donor Coordination Forum (DCF) would be established for EMSRP I1 to ensure effective communications, reporting and monitoring. The DCF would include donors and key Palestinian

Considerable learning has also taken place through a Bank review of donor-financedemergency employment creationprograms in WBG; this exercise was financed by the Bank and carried out in coordination with all donors providing emergency employment assistance through the Sector Working Group on Employment Generation. Many such programs have relied on conventional works-based, largely capital intensive project designs to create temporary employment opportunities and placed much of the burden on contractors to find ways of ensuring maximum labor content. However, because these sub-projects by design are not labor intensive, many of the subprojects featured labor content of no more than 20 percent, thus limiting impact. In response, the PA, the Bank and other donors have agreed to adopt a labor-intensive approach in the designand implementationof these sub-projects inthe future. Technical assistance in project identification, selection, preparation and implementation would be supported through training workshops and capacity building by regionally-basedlocal technical consultants, with support from internationalexperts.
Building on EMSRP's legacy of achievement. In addition to addressing emergency needs, EMSRP also introducedmeasures to (i) strengthen donor coordinationin the sector, (ii) promote greater accountability and public disclosure, as well as local participation, and (iii)establish an institutionalizedmechanism for central-localresourcetransfers. First, EMSRP has introducedthe concept of LG upward and downward financial accountability by requiring public participation and disclosure of the Emergency Assistance Program (EAP) budgets submittedto the MOLG in order for LGs to be eligible to receive assistance. Second, this eligibility requirement was coupled with a requirement for LGs to submit their annual executed and planned budgets, which has resulted in a significant increase inthe number of submissions from 25 in Gaza alone prior to EMSRPto 285 in 2004 in all of WB&G -- over a ten-fold increase. While it was not possible to consider more stringent performance requirements under EMSRP II due to emergency circumstances beyond the control of municipalities, the aim is to build upon the awareness of accountability as a practice established over the past two years by institutionalizing a more predictableand rules-basedsystem.

Project Objectives and Development Outcomes. EMSRP I1 is designed primarily as a repeater project to EMSRP Iand would address many of the same areas of support. Palestinian counterparts indicate that these remain critical areas of need, including assistance to sustain essential municipal services, promote temporary employment generation, while maintaining a medium-termdevelopment agenda. The Projecthas beenprepared in accordancewith the Bank's guidelines for emergency recovery operations (OP/BP 8.5), which are intended to be simple in design, fast disbursingand responsiveto emergency needs aimed at restoringhehabilitatingassets and services. The main objectives of EMSRP I1are to: (i)help mitigate further deterioration in the delivery of essential municipal services, including solid waste collection, street lighting, provision of water, wastewater and electricity services (where such services are provided by municipalities), and street cleaning, among other services, through rehabilitation of damaged or deteriorating infrastructure and the provision of non-wage budgetary support for direct service cost inputs; (ii)create temporary job opportunities at the local level through the launching of labor-intensive employment generation schemes, proportionally allocated on the basis of an unemployment index; and (iii)pilot innovative initiatives that foster Local Government-NGO collaborationin response to urgent community needs and assist municipalitiesin recoveringcosts for the provisionof services. Pre-paid metering (PPM) systems have been tested and are now operating in more than 40 countries around the world Such systems are being used most extensively in the United Kingdom and South Africa where 3 million and 2 million users respectively are covered by this new approach to utility billing. Other countries are mainly in the piloting phases and have somewhere between 100 and 100,000 meters in place. PPM systems are now mature (we know their advantages and disadvantagesthrough multiple testing experiences) and PPM markets are growing internationally. PPM systems have been applied to electricity, water, gas, telephoneand cell phone services. Locally, the JerusalemElectricity Company (JEC) was the first to introduce the new technology on a pilot basisand has done so successfully.
Why introducepre-paid metering? Pre-paid metering systems have been introducedfor a variety of reasons. The main reason has been to improve revenue recovery, but many sources today cite the opportunity to improvecustomer service as another key reason. Elimination of meter readings, as well as billing and mailing can have a significant impact in driving down administrative costs, which pre-paid metering systems have allowedproviders to do. But there are other factors that figure into the pricing of utilities that provide inherent subsidies to some users, while raising the costs for all users. Removingsuch costs or subsidies would allow providersto pass on savings to the general user. For instance, with PPM systems there is no need for credit control, for provisioning for bad debt or arrears or for legal and technical services for disconnectionheconnectionprocesses, all of which are costs that are built into cost recovery charges and tariff rates. Pre-paid metering can also represent a significant cost savings to the extent that it can eliminate the need for postal system services or delivery of bills door-to-door.
Improved energy and water conservation. From an energy conservation and household expenditure management perspective, PPM systems tend to encourage users to better manage consumption, a significant positivespillover effect, particularlyin aresourcescarce regionsuch as the Middle East. Customers are much more in control of their usage and can save money while better monitoringand understandinghow to manage their household consumption. Initially, PPMsystems oftentranslate into revenuedeclines for providersdue to lower average consumption, but system losses are reduced significantly in parallel and capacity can be extendedto achieve greater systemcoverage.
Reduction of bad debts and arrears. Providers have noted experiencing dramatic declines in bad debts and arrears where they have introduced PPM systems. They also note improved cash flow, due to receiving money up front and, hence, improvedrelationswith customers. Customers appear to prefer the flexibility and open system approach o f a PPM system, which allows them to purchase electricity at any time and in any quantity, and to avoidthe end-of-themonthbudget crunch. Moreover, no deposits are required.
Improved means of targeting thepoor through the elimination of costs and subsidies built into the existing system. Through the use o f a range of new payment options and smart technologies, PPM can aid central or local governments in providing targeted subsidies (in-kind support for electricity service to the poorest. Magnetic cards, smart cards, memory cards, keypad tokens and smart tokens are all ways of converting payments into service.
As with all new technologies, the question is how to implement such a system from a technical, organizational, managerial and cultural perspective? First, a pilot design and implementation strategy would be prepared, initially for a pilot project involving no more than three municipalities. Drawing on lessons learned from the Jerusalem District Electric Utility Company, the strategy would take into account most appropriate technologies, customer preferences, technical specifications, public awareness requirements, etc. Policy issues will arise as well, such as whether PPM will be a free choice or forced use system. More successful PPM pilots have been built around an extensive and dedicated external and internal marketing campaign to raise awareness (internal staff, political players, media, community organizations and their representatives, customers), but there is also an extensive need for training; restructuring of management processes, and installationof new meters, all of which is providedfor inthe proposedpilot activity budget.

38  SECTIONE: ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL JUSTIFICATION
The proposed emergency Project is being prepared under emergency recovery assistance procedures (OP/BP 8.50). Time limitations and limited availability of economic data prevent more detailed analysis, a recognized constraint in preparing such operations. The principal benefitofthe Projectwould be to restore essential municipalservices, includingwater supply and sanitation services, solid waste collection, and electricity supply to a significant portion of the Palestinian population. Improved municipal service coverage and quality would help mitigate deteriorating health and sanitary conditions in WBG, reducing health risks while generating economic activity. Infrastructure rehabilitation and maintenance services supported under the Projectwould also reducethe rapid depreciation in the value of municipalassets, includingroads, wastewater treatment facilities, solid waste collection vehicles, transformers and water pumps, thus reducing the burden on the capital budget for replacement costs. In addition, targeted assistance to communities with higher incidences of poverty and unemployment through labor- intensive employment generation subprojects would mitigate some of the harshest effects of the economic contraction.
The proposed Projectwould support demand-driven initiativesto improvemunicipalservicesthat would benefit 131 municipal areas and over 70 percent of the population. While the potential economic benefitsare likely to materialize in these communities, they are difficult to measure in aggregate. However, several measures have been taken in the project design to promote achievement of these benefits. First, a positive list of sub-projects has been agreed, all of which would contribute to improvingthe livelihoods and well-being of the communities in which they are implemented, while screening out alternative uses of funds that would yield little or no benefit. Second, an M&E system would be initiatedby MDLF through the EAP applicationform and MIS database to establish the baseline conditions (service areas to be improved) for each subproject financed under Component l(a), as well as the performance indicator for service improvement. This data would be gathered through the EAP and would be used to populate the MISdatabaseto measure economic and other benefitsin different service areas. Ineach instance where such data can be gathered during the subproject identification and design phase, the number of direct and indirect beneficiariesin the affectedsubproject area would be recordedand tracked.
Bearing in mind the typology of infrastructure to be financed under Component l(a) (no sub- project would exceed US$500,000), the main emphasis is placed on restoring infrastructure services at the lowest cost possible against acceptable industry standards. As such, subproject selection would be justified by applying a least cost approach. This would be confirmed at MDLF's review/appraisalof the proposed subproject. Bank procurement guidelines, which place emphasis on achieving economy and efficiency, would also contribute to this outcome. In instances where budgetary support is being provided for the purchase of spare parts, fuel and electricity (street lighting) attempts to quantify impact will be made in standard units to measure aggregate impact in these service areas and for comparative purposes. No such baseline exists at this time due to the demand-drivennature ofthe project.
In the case of labor-intensive employment generation sub-projects financed under Component 2, least cost methodologies cannot be applied since the emphasis on labor intensity would preclude using capital intensive approaches that may in some cases be less expensive. In such cases, any assets developed under the sub-projects would be considered a positive spillover benefit. As such, measurementof economic benefitswould focus on the number of man-daysof work created under this Component per dollar spent.

In a Quality of Supervision Assessment Report (QSA6) carried out in September 2004 by the Bank's internal Quality Assurance Group (QAG), project supervision for EMSRP I was rated Highly Satisfactory overall. The Task Team and Region were commended for being able to respond to the demands of an emergency operation while also pursuing medium-term development goals. In particular, project design was acknowledged to be sound in the way decentralized, regionally-basedsupport was providedto municipalities through the contractingof regional technical consultants who worked effectively in providing outreach services to the scattered project municipalities. One short-coming of the project, however, was the complexity and difficulty in mobilizing the Management Agent contract, which caused some delay in project implementation and sheds light on the difficulty of undertaking complex assignments requiring substantial internationaltechnicalexpertise.
A particular focus of EMSRP 11, based on the preliminary findings of an Implementation Completion Report (ICR) from EMSRP I,will be to establish a sound and effective system for project impact and results monitoring. Such an approach needs to be designed with caution, as there are factors beyond the control of municipalities that can have an impact on outcomes. Moreover, as an emergency operation, a results focus should be directedat the mainobjectivesof the emergency operation, addressing questions as to how municipal services were enhanced with EMSRP I1 support and with what degrees of efficiency. A combination of factors inherent in EMSRP I1design as an emergency operation, coupled with the fact that it is demand-driven with a significant portion of the financing being provided for recurrent expenditures will make results measurement a challenge. In particular, some elements of budgetary support will be difficult to monitor in terms of their impact. However, in instances where infrastructure rehabilitation is being financed, specific measures to establish baseline indicators have been identified during preparation.
Effective gathering of baseline indicators for activities to be identified by the beneficiary communitieshas already been initiatedand would be a particular focus of the MDLF within the first 6 months of the Project life. The updated Results Framework, including baseline data and targets establishedthrough the screening and approvalof each municipality EAP applicationwill be submitted by the MDLF as an annex to the Quarterly Progress Report (QPR) startingwith the second reporting quarter period. Accordingly, the project will continue to be monitored by the MDLF to ensure that basic tools for managing infrastructure rehabilitated assets and basic municipal services are sustained during the Project timeframe, and that lessons learned are incorporatedto recommend follow up operations, once the conditions allow for a developmental- orientedapproach.

doc.repnme: West Bank and Gaza - Second Emergency Municipal Serevices Rehabilitation Project
doc.abstracts: The main objectives of Second Emergency Municipal Services Rehabilitation Project for West Bank and Gaza are to: (i) help mitigate further deterioration in the delivery of essential municipal services, including solid waste collection, street lighting, provision of water, wastewater and electricity services (where such services are provided by municipalities), and street cleaning, among other services, through rehabilitation of damaged or deteriorating infrastructure and the provision of non-wage budgetary support for direct service cost inputs; (ii) create temporary job opportunities at the local level through the launching of labor-intensive employment generation schemes, proportionally allocated on the basis of an unemployment index; and (iii) pilot innovative initiatives that foster local government-NGO collaboration in response to urgent community needs and assist municipalities in recovering costs for the provision of services.
